Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Finding Evolutionary Links and Genes in Adaptive Radiations of Gobies by Targeted Gene Capture
Award.AbstractNarration:
Gobies comprise a very large, complex group of fishes found in nearly all aquatic ecosystems. Species in this group can serve as models for ecological and evolutionary specializations that have allowed them to radiate into many different habitats. The relationships of gobies will be examined using a new genetic technique that will also reveal the genes that enable adaptations of these species to their environments. Additionally, it will advance understanding of how organisms can change over time and radiate to fill new roles in nature. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Chenhong Li, who developed the original technique, at his laboratory in Shanghai Ocean University. Dr. Li is a leading researcher in systematics who has developed many genetic and statistical tools for the field. His laboratory has access to all equipment and technology needed for gene-capture in this project.

This project will investigate the deep phylogeny of gobies within the Gobiidae using a new gene-capture method to identify signals of directional selection in protein-coding genes across a broad suite of taxa. The ability to combine the identification of loci under selection with the resolution of difficult relationships via gene capture offers unprecedented opportunity to increase the scientific community?s understanding of adaptive radiations and speciation in general. The research funded by this award will accomplish this by creating a high-resolution phylogeny of the Gobiidae using a large number of protein-coding markers obtained by target-enrichment gene capture coupled with broad taxon sampling.

This award, under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program, supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Ministry of Science and Technology of Taiwan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the phylogeny of gobies within the family Gobiidae using a new gene-capture method to identify signals of directional selection in protein-coding genes across a broad suite of taxa. The research funded by this award created a data set of protein-coding genetic markers that will be used to create a high-resolution phylogeny of Gobiidae. The type of data obtained will additionally allow for investigations into the genes that enable adaptations of these species to their environments, thereby advancing understanding of how organisms can change over time and radiate to fill new roles in nature. This will allow for gobies to become models of ecological and evolutionary specialization as well as adaptation.

            Broader impacts: Broaden participation of under-represented groups- Texas A&M University - Corpus Christi is a Hispanic Serving Institution with a commitment to increasing the number of Hispanic and low income students entering and graduating in STEM programs. Using the knowledge obtained during this project, two undergraduates from the TAMU-CC LSAMP program will be mentored, taught the foundations of genomic research, and engaged in gene-capture of further samples. International Collaboration/Enhance Infrastructure for research and education- The Lab of Molecular Systematics and Ecology (LMSE) at Shanghai Ocean University has been an important collaborator, providing guidance on the gene-capture methodology and data processing. In return, the data obtained from this study has been used to test and optimize a new genetic analysis pipeline developed by them.  Data and progress on this project has been communicated to other researchers studying goby phylogenetics, and has opened up opportunities for future collaborative efforts to expand the gene-capture data set and phylogeny of gobies.  Broaden dissemination to enhance scientific and technological understanding- The knowledge gained from this study was be distributed across the TAMUCC campus and more via presentations at research conferences, including the 2017 Indo-Pacific Fish Conference and TAMUCC Graduate Student Symposium. Community outreach will be accomplished through exhibit development at the Texas State Aquarium and presentations to hundreds of high school students each year in the Science Olympiad.

            Intellectual merit: This study proved that gene-capture can be applied to a group with a complex and poorly-understood evolutionary history, and successfully obtain data that can be used to explore functional differences in genes under selection that may have lead to divergence during adaptive radiations. The use of gene-capture data to determine the phylogeny of a complex taxon with rapid diversification has implications for phylogenetic studies of other groups that are difficult to resolve due to explosive periods of speciation, including the early history of the Percomorpha. The ability to combine the identification of loci under selection with the resolution of difficult relationships via gene capture offers unprecedented opportunity to increase the scientific community’s understanding of adaptive radiations and speciation in general.
